metadata.title: Understanding Deep Associative Embedding in Convolutional Neural Networks | by Shuchen Du | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Understanding Deep Associative Embedding in Convolutional Neural Networks
metadata.description: In some tasks of computer vision and deep learning, we need to predict all the results first and then split the results to several individual results. A common task in this spirit is pose estimation…

all_paragraphs: In some tasks of computer vision and deep learning, we need to predict all the results first and then split the results to several individual results.

A common task in this spirit is pose estimation for multi-people, in which the key points for all the people in the image are predicted first and then split into individual pose as the final prediction (Fig. 1).

Another task in this spirit is object detection via detecting and grouping paired key points of objects to form the bounding box, which is a relatively new approach to form the bounding box compared to the R-CNN line of works [Ren et al.]. In their new approach [Law et al.], the bounding box for each object is represented by two key points (upper-left and bottom-right). During inference, the key points for all objects in the image are predicted first and then splitted into individual key-point-pairs to get the final prediction (Fig. 2).

Both of the above works need to split all the predicted key points into individual groups. In order to realize that in a neural network as a side effect, the splitting and grouping algorithm should satisfy two aspects simultaneously: 1) the key points belong to the same object should be correctly assigned to the same group; 2) which key point belongs to which group should be understood inherently, without additional work of labeling.
Associative embedding [Newell et al.] is just a good choice to realize the above discussion.

Let ‘s take multi-people pose estimation for example. In order to group all the predicted key points to each individual, a tag is also predicted along with each key point and the predicted tags should satisfy two aspects: 1) tags of the same person should be as equal as possible; 2) tags of different people should be easy to tell apart. According to these aspects, Newell et al. proposed the following loss function to train the tag values (Equ. 1).
In the loss function, K key points and K tag values are predicted for each of N people, so that NK key points and NK tag values are predicted in total.

The first item (in red) makes tag values of the same person similar by penalizing the deviations of the predicted tag values from their mean. The second item (in blue) makes tag values of different people different by penalizing a Gaussian function whose peak is at the location where the mean tag values of two different people meet, and the loss decreases dramatically as the two mean values deviate from each other (Fig. 3).

With this loss function, the tag values for each person can be learnt automatically without additional labeling. Therefore, associative embedding is fast, light and easy to be embedded to existing deep learning architectures.

As shown in Fig. 4, the right part is the predicted tag values and the left part is the corresponding pose estimations. In the right part, y axis is the index of human key points and x axis is the value of tags. The red circles represent the tag values of detected key points. Because the body parts of some people are occluded, the number of detected key points vary with different people. We can easily see that tag values for different people are clustered in different vertical lines, which is straightforward to be grouped individually.

As a result, associative embedding can group the prediction results to individual level in a precise and light-weight manner. Furthermore, as a common practice in machine learning by simply adding a loss function, associative embedding can not only be used in computer vision tasks, but also a strong ingredient for other tasks in a broader domain of machine learning.
Faster R-CNN: Towards Real-Time Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks, Ren et al., NIPS 2015
Associative Embedding: End-to-End Learning for Joint Detection and Grouping, Newell et al., NIPS 2017
CornerNet: Detecting Objects as Paired Keypoints, Law et al., ECCV 2018
